information.title: Constitutional Provisions
information.description: Article 123 of the Constitution empowers the President to promulgate ordinances during recess of Parliament. Similarly, Article 213 empowers Governors to issue ordinances when the state legislature is not in session.

information.title: Conditions
information.description: An ordinance can be promulgated only when both houses of Parliament (or state legislature) are not in session, and the President (or Governor) is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary to take immediate action.

information.title: Duration
information.description: An ordinance must be laid before Parliament (or state legislature) when it reassembles. It ceases to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly of Parliament (or state legislature), or if resolutions disapproving it are passed by both Houses.

information.title: Limitations
information.description: The President cannot promulgate an ordinance without instructions from the Union Cabinet. Similarly, the Governor acts on the advice of the state council of ministers.

information.title: Scope
information.description: An ordinance has the same force and effect as an Act of Parliament (or state legislature). However, it cannot be used to amend the Constitution or to enact a law which requires a special majority in the legislature.

information.title: Judicial Review
information.description: The Supreme Court has held that the President's satisfaction can be questioned in a court on the ground of malafide. The same applies to the Governor's ordinance-making power.
